info.game_comments:
2007 College Championship quarterfinal game 2.
From the University of Southern California.

(1, 1).clue: It's the only Asian great ape

(2, 1).clue: In 1984 this company's laser printer won raves &, at $3,495, also cost a third less than the competitors'

(3, 1).clue: Jon Stewart got a "kick" out of this sport at William & Mary, & an award there is named in his honor

(4, 1).clue: Pass the grape jelly & name this state capital of New Hampshire

(5, 1).clue: This czar may have been "great", but biographer Robert K. Massie says he was deathly afraid of cockroaches

(6, 1).clue: Immature, wingless feeding stage of an insect

(1, 2).clue: It's what an archerfish shoots to bring down insects

(2, 2).clue: The cover of the first PC Magazine featured this company's new desktop computer, which helped launch an industry

(3, 2).clue: Steve Young was a quarterback at this school named for his great-great-great-grandfather

(4, 2).clue: It's the capital of the Evergreen State

(5, 2).clue: Princess Caroline's hunky son Andrea Casiraghi is second in line to the throne in this country

(6, 2).clue: A portable lamp, or a "Green" DC Comics character

(1, 3).clue: This predator that comes in gray and red types is a bit camera-shy, but its tracks are seen here

(2, 3).clue: For 16 years this computer maker put an ad on the back page of PC Mag to promote & pioneer its direct PC sales

(3, 3).clue: Julia Louis-Dreyfus was part of an improv troupe while attending this university in Evanston, Illinois

(4, 3).clue: Much of the trendy Back Bay area of this state capital is built on a landfill

(5, 3).clue: This "Sun King" sniffed, "England is a little garden full of sour weeds"

(1, 4).clue: A traditional sign of spring in England is a letter to the Times saying, I heard this "crazy" bird's call

(2, 4).clue: In 1999, when it wasn't even a year old, this website won a PC Mag award for its PageRank technology

(3, 4).clue: At Amherst this future TV dad graduated cum laude; he must have been in "7th Heaven"

(4, 4).clue: Because he believed God led him there, Roger Williams named a state capital this

(5, 4).clue: Princess Cristina of this country married a Basque handball player in 1997

(6, 4).clue: Another name for a cowboy's lasso

(1, 5).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew appears from the USC Wrigley Institute on Catalina Island, CA.)  Though thriving now, Catalina Island foxes were threatened in the '90s by the infectious disease marked by fever & catarrh known as canine this

(2, 5).clue: id Software got kudos for letting gamers construct worlds in this 4-letter shooter, set on Mars & featuring demons

(3, 5).clue: At Vassar, Meryl Streep starred in this Swede's play "Miss Julie"; at Yale, she was in his play "The Father"

(4, 5).clue: It's where you'll find the Robert C. Byrd U.S. Courthouse

(5, 5).clue: In 1927 5-year-old Prince Michael was proclaimed king of this country north of Bulgaria

(6, 5).clue: Element with the atomic number 103 (it ain't livermorium!)

(1, 1).clue: After jousting with the Lance, she felt a change would do her good in 2006

(2, 1).clue: In 1935 Lincoln Ellsworth flew over this continent & claimed parts of it for the U.S.

(3, 1).clue: "Gone with the Wind" opens with a description of her "arresting" face

(4, 1).clue: 2-word term for the hypothetical species said to bridge the gap between anthropod apes & human beings

(5, 1).clue: New York's Public Theater began staging Shakespeare in the Park in this park in 1962

(6, 1).clue: Types of these include flexors & adductors

(1, 2).clue: Who will save your soul?  This precious gem, seen here?

(2, 2).clue: DAR co-founder Flora Darling founded a "Daughters of" group for this next declared U.S. war

(3, 2).clue: Use your plastic to pick up "Beauty Junkies: Inside Our $15 Billion Obsession with" this type of "Surgery"

(4, 2).clue: It's the 4-syllable practice of having more than one spouse at the same time

(5, 2).clue: The students who founded this univ.'s Dramatic Society in 1885 included a future Archbishop of Canterbury

(6, 2).clue: This city is on the Black Warrior River in Alabama

(1, 3).clue: Amy Ray & Emily Saliers are better known as this colorful group

(2, 3).clue: In the 1600s Thomas Sydenham pioneered the use of this drug to treat malaria

(3, 3).clue: This author wrote that Dorian Gray had "finely-curved scarlet lips"

(4, 3).clue: From the Latin for "from the beginning", it's the noun used for the earliest known dwellers of a region

(5, 3).clue: In classic commedia dell'arte, many characters wore these on their faces, but the lovers did not

(6, 3).clue: This staple of North African cuisine can be a porridge, a salad or a dessert

(1, 4).clue: This Irish lass is seen performing at the 1998 Lilith Fair concert

(2, 4).clue: Pierre Monteux was the conductor at the uproarious 1913 premiere of this "seasonal" Stravinsky work

(3, 4).clue: Pride & terror mix on Mr. Kurtz' face before he makes this final exclamation

(4, 4).clue: In 1891 prehistoric human fossils given this geographic name were discovered on an Indonesian island

(5, 4).clue: In the 1580s this Spanish novelist reportedly wrote 20 to 30 plays, but only "The Traffic of Algiers" & "Numantia" survive

(6, 4).clue: Red & white blood cells are also called these

(1, 5).clue: She's no criminal, although she often steals the show

(2, 5).clue: Part-time astronomer after whom the capital of Queensland, Australia was named

(3, 5).clue: The heroine of Toni Morrison's first novel wants the blondest hair & this feature, the book's title

(4, 5).clue: At dig sites, these ancient household garbage dumps reveal a great deal about those who used them

(5, 5).clue: The play "Our Leading Lady" focuses on Laura Keene, who was starring in this play the night Lincoln was shot

(6, 5).clue: At age 88 King Gustav VI was out diggin' in the ruins of these people in Acquarossa, Italy

(0, 0).clue: He's the character mentioned in the first line of "Atlas Shrugged"
